text: All the initial influencers, I onboarded manually myself. I would jump on a call with each one of them so that they understood what Gamma represented, how to use the product. You want to be able to have them tell you story but in their voice. I think a lot of people think influencer marketing and they'll think these big trendy creators, people that have a million followers. This is the wrong approach. You basically give them a script to read, immediately feels like an ad.
speaker: Grant Lee
context: Lenny asks Grant about Gamma's influencer marketing strategy, which was a key growth lever for the company. Grant explains his hands-on approach to working with influencers and why targeting micro-influencers is more effective than working with large creators. He emphasizes the importance of authenticity in influencer partnerships rather than treating them as simple advertising placements.
vocabulary_highlights: tell you story but in their voice
text_ko: 초기 인플루언서들은 제가 직접 하나하나 온보딩(onboarding)했어요. 각 인플루언서와 통화하면서 Gamma가 무엇을 대표하는지, 제품을 어떻게 사용하는지 확실히 이해하게 하려고 했어요. 중요한 건 그들이 자기 목소리로 이야기를 하게 만드는 거예요. 많은 분들이 인플루언서 마케팅(influencer marketing)을 떠올리면 팔로워가 백만 명인 트렌디한 크리에이터들만 생각하는데, 그건 잘못된 접근이에요. 사실상 읽을 스크립트(script)를 주면 바로 광고(ad)처럼 느껴져요.
text_zh: 最开始那些意见领袖，我都是一个一个亲自去谈的。我会跟每个人单独打电话，让他们真正理解Gamma是做什么的，产品怎么用。你得让他们用自己的话来讲你的故事，而不是照本宣科。很多人一提到网红营销(influencer marketing)，就想到那些很火的大V，动不动就几百万粉丝的。这种思路是错的。你直接给他们一个稿子让他们念，马上就变成硬广了。
text_es: Todos los primeros influencers los incorporé yo mismo, uno por uno. Me subía a una llamada con cada uno para que entendieran qué representaba Gamma, cómo usar el producto. Lo que buscas es que te cuenten tu historia pero con su propia voz. Creo que mucha gente piensa en marketing de influencers y se imagina estos creadores súper trendy, gente que tiene un millón de seguidores. Ese enfoque está mal. Básicamente les das un guión para leer y de inmediato se siente como un anuncio.
key_sentence: Onboarded manually, I ensured influencers tell their story but in their voice.

text: You're much better doing the hard thing, which is hard to scale, finding the thousands of micro influencers that have an audience where your product maybe is actually useful. People really trust what they say. That ends up becoming this wildfire that can spread really, really fast.
speaker: Grant Lee
context: Grant continues explaining his influencer marketing philosophy, contrasting his approach with traditional influencer marketing. He advocates for working with micro-influencers who have smaller but more engaged audiences that genuinely trust their recommendations. He describes how this strategy creates organic word-of-mouth growth that can spread rapidly through communities.
text_ko: 차라리 확장하기(스케일(scale))는 어렵고 손이 많이 가는 그런 일을 하는 게 훨씬 낫아요. 예를 들어 수천 명의 마이크로 인플루언서(micro influencers)를 찾아서, 우리 제품이 실제로 유용할 수 있는 오디언스를 가진 팔로워들에게 닿게 하는 거예요. 사람들은 그들이 하는 말을 정말로 신뢰하거든요. 그러면 그게 금세, 아주 빠르게 퍼지는 들불처럼 번져요.
text_zh: 你最好还是做那些难做的事儿，虽然不好规模化，但要去找那些成千上万的小网红(micro influencers)，他们的粉丝群体可能真的会用得上你的产品。大家特别信任他们说的话。这样搞下去，就会像野火一样蔓延，传播得特别特别快。
text_es: Es mucho mejor hacer lo difícil, que es complicado de escalar, encontrar a esos miles de micro influencers que tienen una audiencia donde tu producto realmente puede ser útil. La gente confía muchísimo en lo que dicen. Eso termina convirtiéndose en un incendio forestal que se puede extender súper rápido.
key_sentence: Finding micro influencers is hard to scale but builds trust and spreads like wildfire.

text: We would have an idea in the morning, come up with some sort of functional prototype, recruit a bunch of people that are legitimately good prospective users, but have zero skin in the game, ship fast so people can start playing with it. In the afternoon, we're already running pretty full scale experiment. You start actually hearing other people describe their usage of the product. We can also watch them struggle.
speaker: Grant Lee
context: Lenny asks Grant about Gamma's experimental approach to product development. Grant describes their rapid prototyping and user testing workflow, where they can go from idea to user feedback within a single day. This process involves recruiting unbiased potential users to test prototypes and observe their real interactions with the product, allowing the team to identify usability issues quickly.
text_ko: 아침에 아이디어가 떠오르면, 어떤 식으로든 기능적 프로토타입(functional prototype)을 만들어서 실제로 적합한 잠재 사용자들(prospective users)을 여럿 모집해요. 다만 그들은 위험 부담(skin in the game)은 전혀 없어요. 사람들이 바로 써보게 하기 위해 빨리 출시(ship fast)하죠. 오후가 되면 이미 꽤 대규모 실험(full-scale experiment)을 돌리고 있어요. 사람들이 제품을 어떻게 쓰는지 직접 얘기하는 걸 듣게 되고, 그들이 애먹는 모습도 지켜볼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我们早上想到一个点子，马上就能搞出个能用的原型(prototype)，然后找一帮真正的潜在用户来测试——这些人都很合适，但跟我们没有任何利害关系，快速上线让大家先玩起来。到了下午，我们就已经在跑大规模的实验了。这时候你就能听到其他人真实地描述他们怎么用这个产品，也能看到他们在使用过程中遇到的各种问题。
text_es: Teníamos una idea por la mañana, armábamos algún tipo de prototipo funcional, reclutábamos a un montón de gente que realmente eran buenos usuarios potenciales, pero que no tenían nada que ver con el proyecto, lanzábamos rápido para que la gente pudiera empezar a probarlo. Ya por la tarde, estábamos corriendo experimentos a gran escala. Empezabas a escuchar cómo otras personas describían su uso del producto. También podíamos verlos batallar con él.
key_sentence: We ship fast, creating functional prototypes and running full scale experiments with users.

text: I think most people today are probably familiar with founder-led sales, which is still very, very important. I think before you hire your first salesperson or AE, it's great for the founder to understand what it takes. And they're going to craft the right narrative, the right story.
speaker: Grant Lee
context: Grant explains the concept of founder-led marketing by drawing parallels to founder-led sales. He argues that just as founders should understand sales before hiring salespeople, they should also understand marketing and storytelling before delegating these functions. This hands-on approach helps founders develop better narratives and maintain higher standards when working with marketing professionals or influencers.
text_ko: 요즘 대부분 사람들은 창업자 주도 영업(founder-led sales)에 익숙할 거예요. 이 방식은 여전히 정말 중요해요. 첫 영업사원(salesperson)이나 AE(Account Executive, AE)를 채용하기 전에 창업자가 직접 무엇이 필요한지 이해해 보는 게 좋아요. 그래야 적절한 내러티브(narrative)와 스토리(story)를 만들어낼 수 있어요.
text_zh: 我觉得现在大部分人应该都知道创始人亲自做销售这回事，这个确实还是非常非常重要的。我觉得在你招第一个销售或者AE之前，创始人自己先搞明白这里面的门道是很有必要的。而且他们会找到最合适的说辞，讲出最打动人的故事。
text_es: Creo que la mayoría de la gente hoy en día ya conoce las ventas lideradas por el fundador (founder-led sales), que siguen siendo súper importantes. Me parece que antes de contratar a tu primer vendedor o AE (account executive), está genial que el fundador entienda lo que se necesita. Y van a crear la narrativa correcta, la historia adecuada.
key_sentence: Founder-led sales help craft the right narrative before hiring a salesperson.

text: I think there's that saying where obviously if you can have that clarity, that's super important. And most people will try to get super creative with their copywriting, but that's not usually the right way to break through and communicate something. So how do you improve your own copywriting?
speaker: Grant Lee
context: Grant discusses the importance of clear communication in founder-led marketing. He references the principle of prioritizing clarity over creativity in copywriting, suggesting that founders should focus on being understood rather than being clever. This advice comes in the context of explaining how founders can develop better marketing skills by practicing copywriting themselves.
text_ko: 어떤 말이 있잖아요, 메시지를 명확하게 전달할 수 있다면 그게 정말 중요하다고요. 많은 사람들이 카피라이팅(copywriting)을 엄청 창의적으로만 하려고 하는데, 사실 그게 보통은 주목을 끌거나 제대로 전달하는 방법은 아니에요. 그럼 자신의 카피라이팅(copywriting)은 어떻게 개선하면 좋을까요?
text_zh: 我觉得有句话说得对，显然如果你能把话说清楚，这个超级重要。很多人写文案的时候总想搞得特别有创意，但其实这通常不是突围和传达信息的正确方式。那么怎么提升自己的文案写作(copywriting)能力呢？
text_es: Creo que hay un dicho que dice que si puedes tener esa claridad, es súper importante. Y la mayoría de la gente trata de ponerse muy creativa con su copywriting, pero normalmente esa no es la forma correcta de destacar y comunicar algo. Entonces, ¿cómo mejoras tu propio copywriting?
key_sentence: Clarity is super important to break through and communicate effectively in copywriting.

text: I think what I've learned is, even for LinkedIn versus Twitter, the audiences want different things. And so you almost have to then have different tones of voices or even nuggets or sharing. For me, I invested much more in LinkedIn early on just because it felt a little bit more natural for me. And then over time I said, 'Okay, well I'm going to start packaging certain content for Twitter that's actually different than what I would post on LinkedIn.'
speaker: Grant Lee
context: Grant shares his approach to social media marketing across different platforms. He explains how he learned that LinkedIn and Twitter audiences have different preferences and expectations, requiring tailored content strategies for each platform. This insight led him to develop platform-specific approaches rather than simply cross-posting the same content everywhere.
text_ko: 제가 배운 건 LinkedIn이든 Twitter든 청중이 원하는 게 서로 다르다는 점이에요. 그래서 거의 다른 톤(tones of voice)이나 공유 방식, 심지어는 소소한 콘텐츠 조각들(nuggets)까지 달리 가져가야 하더라고요. 저는 초반에 LinkedIn에 훨씬 더 투자했어요. 그쪽이 저한테 더 자연스럽게 느껴졌거든요. 그러다 시간이 지나면서 '트위터에는 LinkedIn에 올리는 것과는 다른 형태로 특정 콘텐츠를 따로 패키징(packaging)해서 올리자'고 생각했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得我学到的是，LinkedIn和Twitter(推特)的用户群体想要的东西是不一样的。所以你几乎得用不同的语调，甚至分享不同的内容点。对我来说，我一开始在LinkedIn上投入得更多，因为感觉更适合我。后来我就想，"好吧，我要开始为Twitter专门包装一些内容，跟我在LinkedIn上发的要有所区别。"
text_es: Creo que lo que he aprendido es que, incluso entre LinkedIn y Twitter, las audiencias quieren cosas distintas. Entonces casi que tienes que manejar diferentes tonos o incluso diferentes tipos de contenido. En mi caso, yo invertí mucho más en LinkedIn desde el principio porque se me hacía más natural. Y luego con el tiempo me dije: "Bueno, ahora voy a empezar a adaptar cierto contenido específicamente para Twitter que sea diferente a lo que subiría en LinkedIn."
key_sentence: Different tones of voices are needed for packaging certain content on LinkedIn and Twitter.
